The only complaint I have is about the pricing on the Japanese wagyu which is very misleading. It was Amazing but absolutely not worth the price. It's $26 per oz for a minimum of 4oz in very small print!!! We had a party of 10 and all of us read the menu wrong. That adds up to $104. We had 3 to share in our table so imagine the shock when we got the bill. $416 for 1lb of wagyu is highway robbery!! If we return I'd like to try the American wagyu. 

PS If you visit be sure to use the restrooms. I know silly but I was so tickled by the Toto high tech toilets lol.
name: The Green Pheasant

text: Y'all, this place is the BOMB! We ate here for the second time. The food is amazing! The spicy crab noodles, chicken wings, Caesar wedge salad, mushrooms, the skirt steak with miso butter, WOW! Nothing like it, plus the atmosphere is amazing! We visit lots of Nashville restaurants and all I can think about is when I'm going back!
name: The Green Pheasant

text:
Keeping in mind that it was lunch and my friend and I had small plates, the score is based on everything from ambiance to presentation to service. I will be returning for dinner and for other samplings. 
Sui Gyoza, perfect beginning. The tuna tartar was elegantly presented and spicy special. We also enjoyed the wedge salad with hibachi dressing and the (very yummy) japanese fried chicken. 
Our server, Alex was top notch and steered us correctly to a dessert to share. We went with the tempura style chocolate cake with both leche and chocolate sauce,  dangerously delicious, but honestly, best shared. Special food, special company. Time well spent.
name: The Green Pheasant

text: We really enjoyed our meal but I was incredibly surprised to see a $2 charge for WASABI when we ordered the chirashi (raw fish).  I understand charging for "extra" wasabi with dumplings or noodles or something but it's pretty standard for wasabi to be included with chirashi.  Lol wtf
name: The Green Pheasant

text: The food was amazing! Highly recommend the Lobster and Corn Dumplings, Spicy Crab Noodle, and the Ni-San cocktail.
name: The Green Pheasant

text:
Have been here a couple of times now and have been blown both times. Service has been quick and attentive, and I love that the servers offer suggestions and let you order throughout the meal. 

Every single item I've tried here has been amazing. The crab noodles are my personal favorite with the chicken gyoza coming in at a close second. 

Also, highly suggest one of the cocktails with the Japanese vodka. They are delicious.
name: The Green Pheasant

text: Favorite restaurant in Nashville for date night. I dream about the spicy crab noodles sometimes. The bar is perfect for a drink with friends and the place itself is beautiful. And for dessert get the chocolate cake thing (can't remember what it's called). It's SO TASTY and unique! Keep doing what you're doing because y'all are killing it!
name: The Green Pheasant

text: We have eaten a lot of food in our lives, but this meal is right up there with the most amazing food ever to enter my pie hole. Wow. We tried the tuna tartare, broccolini, crab noodles, king salmon and wagyu beef. Every dish was its own culinary adventure. I never imagined beef could be like this, and I'm a Nebraska girl!!  The salmon, too, was melt-in-your-mouth. We may have to stop in again sometime to see what else is awesome.
name: The Green Pheasant

text: We had a really great experience here. First, the whole vibe and decor of the place is just so cool and really thought through. If we hadn't had a table I would've been totally fine with sitting at the bar even. They also had a really slick little lounge area too. The food was delicious and different, even the sides were fun to try. Can't wait to go back!
name: The Green Pheasant

text:
With tall ceilings, long wide windows, and green velvet furniture, The Green Pheasant is a good looking place. On a cool and rainy winter night it felt kind of drafty and chilly. But we were excited to check out this new place. 
The menu is simple and split up into two sections: cold and hot. Since it was so chilly we only got one thing from the cold menu: the Tsukemono. I think of Tsukemono as pickled vegetables and was expecting such, but instead got a mixed greens salad with some chunks of raw fish in it. The chunks of raw fish were quite good, and though it seemed like scraps from other raw fish plates, we enjoyed it. I love scraps and not wasting!
We then moved onto our hot plates. When we asked our waitress about the order and timing she promised all of our dishes would not arrive at the same time and she was right. They all arrived at the same time except for the one larger dish we had ordered. Eh, a few kinks to a new restaurant.  I understand. 
The dishes:
Dan Dan shishito. I love Dan dan Mian the spicy Sichuan noodle dish and I like shishito peppers so we got this. It was a competition on the plate: the shishito vs the dan dan. There is not room in the bowl for two such strong flavors! Neither won. 
We then got the kinoko: warm mushrooms with finely grated cheese on top. A salty warm cheesy dish which felt good on a drafty evening. A small bowl for $13 or so but who's counting?
The star of the night was the stuffed chicken wings: the tebasaki gyoza. The bone removed from the meaty half of the wing and a shrimp toast mixture stuffed in, it was warm, savory and my favorite. Three wings on a plate if you were wondering how many to order for a table. 
Finally we got the trout: a good idea of a whole trout lightly fried with cold slaw and three little steamed bread pieces to make your own little baozi
of fish and slaw. Fish was a little overdone and slaw was a little mayo-naisey for our taste. I think we would have preferred a sharper crisper more vinegar heavy slaw. 
Overall, I think it has potential, but needs to work on some execution and pricing. I mean $22 for a bowl for potato udon? Oy!
name: The Green Pheasant

text: Meh. Valet parking is $12. Not a big deal, but nearly every quality dining establishment has free valet these days. The space is definitely beautiful. The food was pretty okay-nothing special. I found it a bit annoying that they refuse to serve any beef dish at any temperature other than medium rare. I'm a medium rare girl myself, but this temperature isn't everyone's cup of tea, and I see no reason why there is zero flexibility on this one. Anyway, the experience was fine, but with all the top-notch competition in town, I don't really see the need to return.
name: The Green Pheasant

text:
One of my favorite restaurants in Nashville. Located across the street from Ascend, The Green Pheasant has a mix of classiness with a good modern vibe. A lot of Japanese inspired dishes and entrees that will make you head spin. Service was excellent!! 

Looking forward to many more visits
name: The Green Pheasant

text: Some of the best food I've had in Nashville! Same owners as Two Ten Jack and they are geniuses with their menu. All small plates so be prepared to order multiple plates. We tried the lobster gyoza, pork fried rice, steak, salmon, and mushrooms. All were delicious. We did order the spicy crab noodles and reminded the waiter multiple times but they never came. He did take them off our check but we're still craving those darn noodles so wish we would've got them. Only reason they get 4 stars.
name: The Green Pheasant

text:
Everything about The Green Pheasant impressed me. The brass hardware paired with bright teal chairs and elevated ceilings gave an upscale, opulent ambiance that I love and is the perfect setting for a fantastic Friday night meal. We met some friends here for the first time and decided to order a lot of things and share. We ordered cocktails, mine was a lemongrass drink with gin that was delicious and the rest of the table had cold sake. For our cold starter we had the wedges which typically I'm not a big fan of a giant stalk of lettuce as a general rule, but this one was cut up into smaller pieces with a hibachi dressing and crispy onions which were delicious. For the warm courses we ordered two kinds of gyozas, one being the stuffed chicken wings which were unlike anything I've ever had and incredibly interesting. They were warm and flavorful and stuffed with a blend of what I think was shrimp and other seasonings. It's hard to describe, but just get them. We also had the dan dan shishito peppers which I have to order whenever they are on a menu and were very good. I think my favorite dish of the night was the spicy crab noodles. They were good because they were actually spicy for a spice lover, and rich but not too heavy unlike other crab noodles I've had. They were incredible and melted in my mouth. I completely hogged the dish and was not as generous with them as I normally am when ordering shared plates. We also sampled a pork special that was great and had a really good sashimi which I think was the walu on the cold menu. 
The Green Pheasant had it all, ambiance, service and most importantly delicious, interesting food.
name: The Green Pheasant

text: This was my fiancé and Is first stop in Nashville. We were not disappointed! The food presentation was exceptional and the food it's self was full of flavor. Each ingredient truly shined through each dish we had. We stoped for lunch and definitely plan to go back for dinner to try out the full menu.
name: The Green Pheasant

text: This place has been on my list to try. Finally got downtown and I'm definitely going to be back. We started with some great Japanese Whiskey cocktails.  Shared the Wedge Salad and the Yaki Gyoza. Both were so perfect; amazing flavor and visual presentation was perfect. Then for dinner we shared the Okonomiyaki and the Spicy Crab Noodle. Again... the taste just made us want to savor each bite. We will be back!!! Sooooooo Delicious. Thank you!!!
name: The Green Pheasant

text: Amazing decor. Excellent food. However, this brings new meaning to the phrase "small plates." Was with a group of eight for a business dinner and it was impossible to maintain a fun vibe with everyone on the hunt for food. If plates are meant for sharing, then they should not be small - in fact, they should be on the large side. These servings were teeny-tiny and it became such a distraction to keep ordering over and over again, so we gave up. That's a shame, because I did try some amazing things and enjoyed flavors I hadn't known before. Perfect for a date, but groups of 3+ stay away!
name: The Green Pheasant

text:
First time I visited I wasn't impressed. The service nor the food was impressive. But gave it another try and glad I did and my opinion has changed. 

I believe they changed the menu and for the better. The food was amazing. Something for everyone. And the service was great. Desiree was amazing!  She was patient with our group of 6!  

Food service was prompt. Everyone loved it. Will definitely be back!
name: The Green Pheasant

text:
The family has a great time at The Green Pheasant. Asian food is a crowd pleaser and all the different dishes let us experiment. Our server even said the  restaurant is modeled after an izakaya, a Japanese pub.

We enjoyed all the dishes (i.e. the plates were empty when they left the table.) but the fried oysters and pheasant dumplings were the favorites. We probably could have eaten those all night. Most interesting/new experience was the bok choy salad.

It is always good to know a place where you can sit and talk while eating top quality dishes. Enjoy.
name: The Green Pheasant

text: I never write reviews but the ramen was the BEST ramen i have ever had in my life !!! The broth was so flavorful and silky in texture. (Wonder how long it took to prepare) The pork belly was tender and there was a whole egg in there!! Oh my god AMAZING. Service at the bar was fantastic too. I'm going every week.
name: The Green Pheasant

text:
One of the most delicious dinners I've had in Nashville, and I've had some amazing ones. 

You must get the chicken wings stuffed with shrimp. They were so good we ordered 2. 

The salmon, spicy crab noodles and broccolini were out of this world. 

I didn't immediately think this place would have a worthwhile dessert to splurge on, but we ordered the tempura chocolate cake and it was unbelievable. 

Must go.
name: The Green Pheasant

text: Absolutely delicious and a welcome reprieve from the bachelorette insanity that downtown now caters to. The roasted cauliflower had amazing flavor with the perfect amount of crispy bits and a hint of heat. The lobster shumai are other worldly, melt in your mouth, dumpling treats. We also loved the roast pork and cabbage dish. The space is beautifully designed and their bar program on point with excellent cocktails and a robust sake collection. Highly recommend a visit.
name: The Green Pheasant

text:
If half stars were allowed I'd give it 3 1/2. Brought the family here for dinner after reading the reviews. It's a Japanese restaurant with a tapas type menu. Saw a ton of things we were interested in trying so ordered about 10 dishes or so. 

It was odd because each time we tried something we'd all look at each other and say "interesting!"  The tuna tartare was not my favorite. Though an interesting presentation, it honestly lost the actual tuna in the dish!  The chirashi was also underwhelming. The lobster shumai was just average. 

On the positive side we really liked the Japanese pancake dish a lot. It had potato, ham and a nice little crunch/sauce. Quite tasty. The spicy crab noodles were also good. I think our favorite was the whole trout. It comes with a great little slaw and some steamed buns (though only 3 buns and 4 ppl!) 

Overall we decided that we were glad we came but probably wouldn't make it a regular in our rotation.
name: The Green Pheasant

text: Best new restaurant in Nashville, hands down. The food we had was solid but we just went with a bunch of small plates that we shared. Looking forward to having some main dishes next time! Details, Details, Details.... everything about the dining experience and ambience was very well done. The service was excellent- looking forward to coming back again.
name: The Green Pheasant

text:
I appreciated the atmosphere of this restaurant, and visiting from out of town, I was happy to see an asian food option. 

The bartender really saved me from rating this restaurant one star down, here's why:

I ordered a Chirashi bowl, and when I asked for wasabi, I was upcharged $5 for wasabi that wasn't even good - the wasabi was tasteless. Consider being upcharged for wasabi with your sushi - that's like getting charged for ketchup with your fries, or getting charged for butter with your toast. Just doesn't make sense. I also had to wait an extra amount of time to get the wasabi and soy sauce. Since I didn't know about this charge while ordering, I passed the $ threshold in my bill where I now have to go submit an expense report. What an annoyance! The rice was on the stiffer side, and the fish was cut into small cubes, which is not ideal. 

The bartender apologized for having to upcharge me, and his kindness made up for it. Otherwise I would've left the restaurant sort of pissed.

Overall though, I appreciated the restaurant's vibe and the staff's courtesy. The cucumber appetizer I had was delicious.
name: The Green Pheasant

text: Food is good, but overpriced. Disappointed that they only serve their ramen dishes at lunch, not dinner. For such an expensive place, the fact they refused to split checks was ridiculous and infuriating as we had a party of four and had to spend ten minutes trying to figure out which dish was whose and how much each person owed (the dishes are small so you order multiple ones which adds to the confusion). When the waiter told me they don't split checks, I thought he was joking and I literally said "are you serious??" out loud to the dismay of my poor husband. Service is also poor and they only check on you once or twice. When we went for lunch, the place was empty, yet we had to get up and find our waiter just to get our check and get out of there.
name: The Green Pheasant

text:
So delicious!! Everything we ordered was amazing except the calamari (ika karaage), which was unfortunately very bland.

Keep in mind that this is a tapas style restaurant so be mindful that you'll be sharing and ordering small plates. 

Also, they have a cake fee. I think it was $25 to have them store the cake in the back and also cut and serve the cake for you.
name: The Green Pheasant

text: To call this place a Japanese restaurant may be one of the bigger insults. I am a fan of Two Ten Jack and was excited about trying Green Pheasant. Boy was I let down. When we walked in the music was positively blaring. When we said something to our server he told us that we were not the first, but the fourth person to complain. When they turned it down, it hardly made any difference. I started with the tuna tartare with crispy rice. We thought they brought out the wrong dish because the tuna was unrecognizable, looking like chopped liver on rice. (See photo). They charged for soy sauce and for wasabi which I have never seen before at a Japanese restaurant. They are trying to get rid of the American influences so did not have the American whiskies on the menu. The food was doused in butter and you could hardly taste the Japanese flavors in any of the dishes. My lips were puckered because the food is so over salted. And to seal the deal, we found a hair mixed into the rice of our chirashi. I will not be coming back. At the end of our meal, the a server came out and let us know he saw our review. Rather than apologizing for the poor service and our bad experience, he could not have been more unkind. One of the wait staff walked us out of the restaurant telling us how pathetic we are. To call one pathetic is incredibly rude, especially to customers in the service industry who simply voiced their opinions of a bad experience on yelp.
name: The Green Pheasant

text: The waitress was very nice and knowledgeable.  The dishes were very heavy and overly greasy.  We ordered the chicken wings gyoza which was ok but greasy.  The hash browns we drenched in BBQ sauce which was overwhelming.  The fried rice was ok, but again with the sausage.  It was just greasy and heavy.  We really wanted to like it.
name: The Green Pheasant

text: Three of us stopped in and had an amazing dining experience! The hostess, Megan, greeted is joyfully and seated us quickly. The menu was different than I'd ever seen before. Each item we ordered served four people and it was so delicious! The tomatoes, mushrooms, lobster... It was all so yummy. Our waiter Michael explained all the dishes well and made great suggestions! We will definitely be back. We do recommend making a reservation to guarantee a table! You will not be disappointed!
name: The Green Pheasant

text:
Amazing on all fronts. 

Guys, park in the self park garage and get it validated for free. Don't pay $12 for valet, silly!

We were seated immediately by a friendly hostess and given warm eucalyptus towels which were SO nice on a cold night. What a nice touch. 

We had the sonomono, shumai, chahan w/american wagyu, and the ora king salmon. Each dish was flavorful and delicious. The sonomono is like ceviche but better. For dessert, we had the tempura chocolate cake - my husbands choice because I usually don't love cake but this was excellent.

The japanese old fashioned was probably one of the best I've ever had. My husband enjoyed his cocktail too - the green chartreuse gave it a complex flavor. 

I'm looking forward to trying more items on the menu next time.
name: The Green Pheasant

text: Place is so good. Highly recommend. Went with a large group and every loved what they ordered which is rare.
name: The Green Pheasant

text: This was the best overall dining experience I've had in Nashville in years. The staff was kind from when we were greeted at the door, to when our awesome waiter walked us through the menus and took great care of us. The vibe inside is modern and stylish, the food was delicious, they have tons of sake options, and the prices were decent! Two Ten Jack is owned by the same people, and both restaurants know what's up!
name: The Green Pheasant

text: Look everyone comes to Nashville for the BBQ and Hot Chicken however, after a few days of that your mouth needs a different flavor.  We had a great meal at the Green Pheasant.  Authentic and modern, the dishes were all hits except the chicken gyoza.  Didnt love those.  Nice drinks and great asian flavors
name: The Green Pheasant

text: Amazing, inventive cuisine. The salmon is mind blowing, literally best salmon I've ever had. Another of my favorites is the crab noodles. Super comforting in this cold weather (but I'm sure I'll eat it when it's sweltering out too)! The American waygu is amazing- almost melt in your mouth. The sake on tap is nicely rice-y and feels like it has the tiniest effervescence. And then for dessert, don't miss out on the strawberry chocolate chip mochi if they have it!
name: The Green Pheasant

text: Awesome unique and tasty food, beautifully presented. Crab noodles, beef dish, and chicken gyoza and ginger creams brûlée were excellent. Brocollini was a bit too salty. Choc cake tempura cake was ok.
name: The Green Pheasant

text: Fantastic dining experience.  Knowledgeable staff helped us make menu choices.  Everything we had was outstanding.  We need to come back so we can try more.  Great atmosphere.  Highly recommend
name: The Green Pheasant

text:
Excellent spot! Definitely get the menu run down!! 

We tried a few small plates!
karaage (fried chicken- small plate- so yummy!)
sui gyoza (pheasant dumplings- when in Rome)

spicy crab noodles- spicy and super delicious! 

kaisendon was my main dish! It was very tasty but needed a balance with some crunch. 

Overall great experience- SUPER friendly staff and not a big wait time in food. Definitely check it out if you are in the area!!
name: The Green Pheasant

text: My friend and I arrived to a near empty restaurant around 5PM. As soon as we walked in we were asked if we had a reservation to which we stated no. We were told by the hostess to sit at the bar since we did not have a reservation. We were a little confused but obliged. The bar was extremely sticky and uncomfortable to be at. We were sitting near the entrance of the restaurant and another group of people walked in and stated that they did not have a reservation, however they were quickly seated at a table. My friend and I went on to order a drink and start with a small plate. The small plate we had was the lobster dumplings and they were extremely salty, we could hardly taste the lobster meat. We ended our dining experience at that and left quite unsatisfied. The customer service here is extremely subpar. I felt as if the staff didn't really want us here. Save your money and explore the many other amazing options Nashville has to offer.
name: The Green Pheasant

text: Great food! This atmosphere is nice and the service was not overwhelming. I highly recommend the chicken/shrimp gyoza. It wasn't what I would've expected but was delicious.
name: The Green Pheasant

text: Absolutely incredible!!!!!!!!! We tried one of everything on the menu and not a single thing disappointed!!! I'd give 10 stars if I  could
name: The Green Pheasant

text:
We came here on a reference assuming there was sushi....there is not. But we grabbed some happy hour apps for a late lunch and those were pretty tasty but nothing to write home about. The noodle dish was my favorite -- like a ramen basically. The decor was modern with some velvet old fashioned touches. The staff was nice as well.

The restaurant was basically empty but it looked like they do small group get togethers and take you through food tastings. Also - bathrooms have fancy toilet seat attachments with heat and all sorts of settings if you're into that!
name: The Green Pheasant

text:
Loved it! This place isn't just a restaurant, it's an experience. They have Toto toilets! They seriously thought this through in every way imaginable. 

We stopped in for lunch and I got yakisoba; wok fired noodles, pork, vegetables with a sunny egg and my husband ordered a sando set, a la bento box-esque with pork katsu. His meal came with miso soup, side of the day, rice, and pickled veggies. The veggies in my dish were super fresh and bright. The chopped asparagus was a nice touch. To round it out we ordered two house sakes (cold) with our meal for $6 a glass.The food was on point and we were very satisfied. I wasn't too full, it was just the right amount. 

The decor is fantastic and romantic. They used a lot of deep jewel tones in the fabrics. The booths were microfiber in a deep burnt orange color and others were a deep blue. The chairs were a little mod and the bar open. The booths were tucked away where you could get some privacy. The tables evoked more of a traditional dining experience. 

To say I was surprised would be incorrect, this team knows what they are doing and consistently delivers top notch food. Two Ten is one of my favorite restaurants in town! I can't wait to come back to the Green Pheasant and try more of their food. There are at least 10 more items I need to eat. This is a must try downtown. It's really opened up the dining scene and filled a much needed void.
name: The Green Pheasant

text:
This place was just ok. We started with  tsukemono 
(seasonal japanese pickles) and they were ok at best, really more vinegar taste than anything else. Next, yaki gyoza (grilled pheasant dumpling) was subpar and I actually asked for sriracha to give it some sort of flavor. We ordered the kinoko (mushrooms) and these were the best thing of the meal in my opinion. Lastly, we decided to stop at the spicy crab noodles. I was really looking forward to this dish and I was let down again. It was basically Alfredo sauce with crab meat and hint of heat. Overall the food was underwhelming. The service was great and our server really talked up the fusion of izakaya and Tennessee charm but in my opinion they missed the  mark.
name: The Green Pheasant

text: This place is gorgeous inside! We ordered the ora king salmon with the teriyaki glaze and bok choy, the spicy crab noodles, the okonomiyaki with ham, bacon, scallops, and potatoes, and finally the broccolini accompanied with hot rock shrimp, cornbread, sudachi, and shoyu. The noodles were our favorite followed closely by the broccolini. The service is great and the flavors will impress you at every turn. Pairing it with cold sake really brought everything together. I would love to come again!
name: The Green Pheasant

text:
The atmosphere and decor really set this restaurant apart.  It is cozy but modern with big teal booths and modern Asian decor throughout.

Service is top notch.  Our server was willing to give us a complete run-down of the menu, noting all of his favorites and specials along the way.  He also gave us some recommendations on saki to try, since it was my first time ever tasting it.  

The saki was good, but not quite my thing, so I ended up with the 'bad sleep well' as my cocktail of choice for the night.  It was so refreshing and delicious.

As far as food goes, I definitely recommend getting a few small plates and entrees to split amongst the table, so you can get a taste of everything.  There were just two of us, so we started with the shishito peppers and the tebasaki gyoza (which is a really cool play on chicken wings and gyozas).  Those gyozas were definitely our favorite!  For our main course we split a pork belly ramen special that was delicious! This is not your typical ramen, it had thick noodles with a thick sauce, which I actually preferred to the more traditional "soupy" ramen dishes.
name: The Green Pheasant

text: This is a really great place to go with a lot of people. Amazing dishes to split and great service. The sashimi is great, and the gyoza is really amazing. No problems with the food, great location, amazing servers, just great all around
name: The Green Pheasant

text: I had a wonderful Galentine's dinner here and our server Lauren was amazing. She shared which ones were her favorite and what she recommend according to our likes. All the dishes were yummy and flavorful. I will go back soon but this time with the hubby since he was a little jealous of our meal :)
name: The Green Pheasant

text:
A beautifully decorated restaurant...downstairs...around the bar. We sat upstairs and unfortunately it could have been a room.... anywhere. 

Our server was excellent and the menu quite attractive.  We decided to do as the server suggested and enjoy a shared menu.  I love the Japanese style fusion options and there were quite a variety.  

Started off with the wedge and this I can not recommend highly enough. Who would have ever thought a "wedge" could be done uniquely on a stick? Crunchy onions on top and that dressing.... I have decided to try to imitate that one at home - it won't be the same, but just the presentation - yum. The cauliflower was highly recommended and we all decided it was the least impressive of the evening. The ikineri steak was amazing - large portion and quite tender. And the spicy crab noodles - wow.  A hint of spice - not too much. With butter... yep. What a bowl of heaven. 

Try to sit downstairs and have a great sampling of the wonderful options.
name: The Green Pheasant

text: This was such a fun experience! Our server was awesome, the food was fantastic. I have a shellfish allergy, told the server, and the chef went out of their way to accommodate me and make sure i was alright. The ambience was awesome. It was a great chill place with a really cool vibe. Also the saki was fantastic.
name: The Green Pheasant

text:
First off holy shit, this place is amazing from the start the hostess gives you oshiburi's (hot towels to wash your hands) the cocktail's menus are decorated with awesome Japanese inspired art. The spirits and sake list is located under the table in a secret pocket. They have a sake somm. Who is very knowledgeable about her selection and it's not small by any means, the Japanese whisky list is also very impressive I got to try a few whisky's I haven't tried yet.

We started with a few cold items the wedges which were awesome very light crisp and full of flavor, first off everything is full of flavor. The tsukemono was perfectly seasoned and fresh, the chirashi was also very fresh and had walu, oprah, and ora king salmon. I definitely reccomend starting with the cold before the hot because the dishes come out as ready. After chatting with the sake somm. And ordering a bottle of the otokoyama we ordered from the hot list. Jesse our waiter was very helpful with our questions and very attentive to our table. We ordered the (pics available) Dan Dan shishitos, the brocolini with rock shrimp (order this please) the kinoko which is a mushroom miso flavor bomb, the ika karaage which is basically tempura squid, the spicy crab noodle is a must every noodle is covered in great sauce the noodles al dente (another please order)the shuman came next and they didn't disappoint either but now I'm starting to think I ordered too much oops... on to the Jidori chicken a never ever chicken and I don't mean not to order it, it was fried to perfection came with a kewpie mayo and a sweet and spicy sauce. I just meant it's a strain of chicken that's DNA has never been tampered with by humans and is raised in completely open pens not the kind PETA shows in those tapes and fed an organic Vegan diet. On to the beef I'm dying a happy death at this point... the first two to show up was the mishima ranch American wagyu and the A5 miyazaki prefecture wagyu both very tender and cooked to perfection the American wagyu has more bite to it but the A5 is like seared foie gras melt in your mouth yummy goodness. Last but not least the American skirt steak showed up ... truly a sizzling flavor bomb the corn the onions the miso butter and the j sauce make sure to get everything in one bite for the perfect bite. I've been writing so much I forgot to talk about the trout just check the pictures ... kudos to chef Kynsey and her amazing staff the GM Michael seale for coming to the table and chatting with us Kristin breringson for the awesome recommendations and most of all Jesse for taking care of us and making sure put needs were met. I will definitely be back just make sure you try it too the place is awesome. Best culinary experience in Nashville.
name: The Green Pheasant

text:
I had been looking forward to eating here for several weeks. My expectations were met in every way. The service was excellent; the cocktails were excellent; and the food was outstanding. 

The Sunomono was a real stand out as were the Spicy Crab Noodles, Ora King Salmon and Broccolini. The absolute star of the show was the Japanese Wagyu. Pricey? Yes, but it was simply excellent. 

The Japanese inspired cocktails were outstanding and our server was excellent in recommending various sakes to try.

For dessert our party tried pistachio mochi, ginger creme brûlée, and tempura chocolate cake.

This place is not cheap. You are ordering small plates that are meant to be shared, so you can run up a pretty expensive tab really quick. The food that you receive however is top shelf all the way. This is now one of my favorite spots in Nashville.
name: The Green Pheasant

text:
A fun food fine for lunch or dinner. A well curated environment with an equally well designed menu and plate presentation. 
Friendly staff and attentive service.
name: The Green Pheasant

text: This place is amazing!! I love the environment of this restaurant. The food was incredible. I had the spicy crab noodles - will definitely come back if I come back in town!
name: The Green Pheasant

text:
in town from SA, TX and DAMN! in my best Kendrick Lamar voice. 

Waygu!
Stuffed wing!
tuna tartare!
Karaage! 
Gold can Sake!
Tremendous waitress!
Great Lunch!  
Better Dinner!

My tastebuds thank you very much!
name: The Green Pheasant

text: Loved Green Pheasant. We went with another couple and it was about $100 per couple, food and drinks included. This is great for Nashville. Every plate we tried was great - mushrooms, sausage fried rice, ikinari steak, SPICY CRAB NOODLES, and all of the sashimi. Recommend for lunch or dinner!
name: The Green Pheasant

text:
This place was not inexpensive, but I was prepared for that after seeing a very helpful picture of their menu. I enjoyed my visit, I ate at the bar and the bartenders were great, both giving me space to eat, and also not neglecting me. I ordered a "cold" item and a "hot" item. I felt that the Hamachi was a day or so older than it should have been, with a slightly fishy taste, but nevertheless the food was very tasty. Great combination of apple, jalapeno and a crunchy item which I'm too unsophisticated to identify. The salmon "hot"item was great and exactly what I was looking for. The food combined with the locally brewed Proper  Sake made for a great meal.
I would return.
name: The Green Pheasant

text: We tried several of the dishes.  Nothing great.  Very bland.  If you just need some overpriced, untasty, sustenance, this will do.
name: The Green Pheasant

text: My wife and I had 7 items. Next time it'll be 14. So dang good. Server Sam was most gracious, especially when my card was declined because it was deactivated. That's skill! Jess and Trey are doing exciting things in this town and my tummy is thankful.
name: The Green Pheasant

text: Went to Green Pheasant last week to entertain clients in from Minnesota.  I had been prepped by a couple of my colleagues that the food was "life changing" and, I am pleased to say, that they did not disappoint.  Between the 5 of us, we ordered probably 15 different small plates and **every** one was exceptional.  In particular, the Spicy Crab Noodles, Wagyu Steak, and Gyoza were excellent.  Our server was outstanding and very informative.
name: The Green Pheasant

text: This was by far one of my favorite restaurants in Nash! The atmosphere and food were amazing. Will be returning on my next trip.
name: The Green Pheasant

text: The worst $140 (for two), I've ever spent in a restaurant. Small plates indeed. The website makes the place look glamorous and beautiful, but we were shown to an area, upstairs, that reminded me of an employee break room. The $28 sushi was good, everything else was tiny, bland, or just plain not as it was described. A $16 plate described as pork was actually peppers. Pretentious, underachieving and overpriced.
name: The Green Pheasant

text: Amazing experience at this beautiful new addition to the downtown dining scene. The host was warm and seated us immediately, manager checked in to make sure all was great, and our server Lauren V was one of the best we've had in town. Extremely knowledgeable, and every single recommendation she gave was fantastic. The spicy crab noodle dish was the highlight, and the broccolini and chicken gyoza were fantastic as well. For a refreshing, light dessert, the blueberry mochi was delicious, and the tempura fried chocolate cake was rich and indulgent. Drinks were thoughtful and unique and a perfect compliment to the meal. The gin and ginger cocktail (golden boy, maybe?) was my favorite. Can't wait to return and try more!
name: The Green Pheasant

text:
We have been three times....the food has been perfectly prepared.   the flavors have been perfect with each dish.
The Steamed Pheasant was bland for us.
Last night the daily fish sashimi, crab noodles, mushrooms, & skirt steak were all perfect.
The wait service has been perfect for each visit....
Thank you for an incredible addition to dining in BNA.
name: The Green Pheasant

text:
I went here for a celebratory dinner with my stepmom and this place was absolutely amazing. 

The ambiance and decor is unparalleled. Lush green velvet everywhere, high ceilings, origami centerpieces hanging above the bar. 

The food was absolutely marvelous and subtly balanced Southern and Japanese influence. We had the mushroom dish, the walu, the spicy crab noodles, and the whole trout. 

The mushrooms were divine. The walu was so delicate with just a little spice. The spicy crab noodles had the best slightly chewy texture, the crab itself was a very fine texture and flavored the noodles, and it had just the right amount of heat in the back of your throat. The trout was amazing because of the salted crust, the meat just fell off the bones. We made little buns with their upscale cole slaw and it was jaw dropping. 

Such a delicious evening that I will cherish always.
name: The Green Pheasant

text: Stopped here Saturday November 10 prior to the Mavericks concert.     Very trendy decor, staff very pleasant, and really interesting cocktails.     The food was great, we had the Wedges for a starter, nice dish with the added carrots and onions.   We shared 4 entrees, all were excellent.  We'll be back, a really nice experience.
name: The Green Pheasant

text:
What an epic bummer! Such a devastating let down to be given dish after dish of tasteless uninspiring dishes. It's actually quite a feat to make six dishes in a row taste like nothing. I mean nothing. No taste, no flavor, nothing. 
How sad. The interior is beautiful and our server Josh was lovely however to pay top price for probably the most tasteless meal I've had all year was the most epic bummer of 2018.
name: The Green Pheasant

text: My wife and I had a great meal with friends Friday night- delicious, interesting food at a very fair price. Cool vibe and friendly staff! Highlights were the shishitos, broccolini, spicy crab pasta, and the ikinari steak. Look forward to our next visit!
name: The Green Pheasant

text:
My wife and I spent three days in Nashville in a food and booze coma and we both agreed that our dinner at the Green Pheasant was far and away our best meal. Things got off to an inauspicious start as we barely made our reservation and the host staff gave my wife a hard time about being alone as I refused to pay the going rate for parking nearby or the posted valet price ($5 self park is available, oops missed that). Once we finally got settled in, our server took over and he was outstanding. 

We ordered a bottle of wine and a number of dishes to share. Everyone raves about the spicy crab noodles and for good reason. Ours could have been a touch hotter in my opinion but once I had that first butter savory umami bite I couldn't part with it. I would come back here often just for this dish alone. We also fell in love with the Tebasaki gyoza. At first when they brought it to our table we were confused as we expected some traditional dumplings, but when our waiter explained how the dumpling filling is stuffed into the chicken wing we raised our eyebrows a bit, took a bite and were astounded at the taste and experience of such an innovative concept. It's hard to surprise me with food and yet this did. My wife still talks about this dish and for good reason. Mindblowingly amazing! We had the broccolini and shrimp dish as well which was fantastic, but compared to the other dishes we ordered, was not in the same stratosphere. Great but not innovative or life-changing. We had the cheapest steak on their menu, which in hindsight I wish I would have insisted on the wagyu or something, but my wife devoured the american steak and claimed it as her favorite steak for some time (I assume that excludes my weekly sous vide offerings). I found the steak befitting of the other dishes and the exquisite ambiance. As much as I enjoyed it, I would def order the crab noodles and gyoza again, but would be interested in trying a different steak next time. 

The restaurant is gorgeous, elegant and stately without being pretentious or overstated. We would definitely return regularly and I know if I were ever in the doghouse, a visit to the Green Pheasant would be just the ticket to get me back in my wife's good graces. Highly recommend.
name: The Green Pheasant

text: We had a wonderful meal here with attentive service. The food was all really flavorful--my favorites were the spicy crab noodles and the broccolini. A great place to come and share plates with everyone. We will absolutely come back.
name: The Green Pheasant

text:
I am baffled to read all the 5 star reviews, if I could I wouldn't even give it a 1 start. This place is very nice inside and reading the reviews I expected a good meal. 
First, we ordered Gyoza for appetizer and it was awful. It was like eating a day old gooey pocket of fish. I told the waitress I was in the mood for ramen and she recommend the "most traditional" which was the shio wontonmen. I can't even describe how tasteless this ramen was, it had no flavor at all. It was cold noodles in a watered down wonton soup. I didn't finish either one, got our checks and left. 
The host gave us a "parking validation" that took off .54 cents from the price of the parking. 
Will I go back?
No thanks.
name: The Green Pheasant

text: I literally came here twice in one week because I wanted to try more things on the menu. Everything is DELICIOUS. My personal favorites are the Walu and the Tuna appetizer. Expect to spend some money on this food but it will be worth it!
name: The Green Pheasant

text:
A great place, BUT the service was absolutely appalling. I was looking for a fun place to go out and celebrate and a lot of my friends recommended this place. The atmosphere was super cute, food was good our server, Matthew was atrocious. We had to ask him repeatedly for multiple things and one of the most important things was water. Water is one thing you shouldn't let run out with customers. 
It took them a significantly (20 mins) longer time to bring out my friends food and she ordered the same thing. Then when it was brought out, wrong might I add, he had an attitude about it and did not offer another option or apologize about the issue. 
Overall I'm not sure if I'll come back to this restaurant let alone recommend this place to anyone else. Now when people ask me about it, the first thing that comes out is food was good, but the service is terrible and that's such a turn off. Very dissatisfied. 
I gave this place one star because the food was good but all the other stars get taken off for the poor service. Come on Nashville get it together!!
name: The Green Pheasant

text: Talk about a fresh, modern, and most importantly delicious take on Japanese cuisine. I was very surprised to find such a gem so close to the heart of Honky Tonk, Nashville, Tennessee. The interior and service were astounding. We were promptly seated and given warm, damp towels to wash our hands at the table. That's something I've never seen before but apparently it's a custom at legitimate Japanese establishments, especially higher budget ones. Our server was very polite and the whole place gave off a formal vibe. I definitely wouldn't come here on a whim in your Wednesday Worst but don't feel pressured to come in a suit or dress. Anyways, the menu items were expectantly  priced for the type of venue Green Pheasant was. I don't think anything was below $10 and one of their entrees was around $25 per ounce (minimum of 4 ounces per order) for examples. Even though the price can be a bit steep, the food was well worth it and tasted delicious. You get an adequate and satisfying portion unlike some more higher end places so you don't feel like you paid for one little piece of meat or lettuce. I recommend the Jidori Chicken and Fried Chocolate Cake. Overall, this is a great place for a casual-formal date or nice family dinner!
name: The Green Pheasant

text:
Totally, 100% worth every single penny.  I planned a surprise birthday dinner for my best friend here, and everything from the moment I called to inquire about availability was flawless and above average customer service.  Karah, the manager I spoke with, worked closely with me to make sure all details were handled, down to prepping the hostesses not to mention a party when I arrived with the birthday girl.  Karah not only helped me the day I called (a week or so before the party), but reached out the day of to go over final details.  She was enthusiastic and thorough.  In fact, she even came by to wish the birthday girl a happy birthday and stopped back a few times to ask if everything was going well. 

Our server, Duane was flawless!  He gave us an enthusiastic overview of the restaurant, it's food and suggestions.  He explained everything extremely well and made our experience personal and exceptional.  He always had a smile on his face and gave wonderful suggestions, i.e. the onset egg on the wagyu steak!  

The FOOD!  THE FOOD THE FOOD!  We spent roughly $1200 for a group of 13 and there wasn't a crumb left on any of the plates!  People made NOISE while eating.  The food is so well prepared, came out in waves (never allowing anything to get cold, it came out immediately when ready), very well presented and perfect for a large group to share.  The cocktails were delicious as well.

Overall, the wait staff, the managers and every single thing about our experience was top notch and well worth every penny.  I highly recommend The Green Pheasant!  Thank you so very much for making a special occasion even more special and completely positive.  Cheers!
name: The Green Pheasant

text:
Was recommended to visit this fine establishment from a local we met at LA Jackson while having an afternoon cocktail. Booked our reservation on Opentable for 8:30....

Upon arrival the restaurant was dimly lit and smelled delicious. We were seated at a table by the window. Our server, Jason, promptly brought hot towels. I thought it was a nice touch.

After reviewing the wine menu we decided to go with a bottle of Italian red. 

For an appetizer we ordered the pheasant dumplings. These things were AMAZING. Tangy and not to filling, we absolutely destroyed them instantly.

For the entree we decided to go with the Japanese wagyu with a side of roasted cauliflower. I highly recommend these delicious cuts of beef if you decide to come here. It arrived on a slate platter with 4 optional topics. We sprinkled the salt and pepper over the top and began to enjoy. The wagyu was everything I hoped and dreamed for it to be. Thinly sliced with a charred exterior, we went with rare plus, every piece was savory and delicious. It was like candy. The pictures do not do it justice!

Would go again next time we're in Nashville.

JM
name: The Green Pheasant

text: Great restaurant right in the heart of downtown Nashville! Perfect as a date-night spot or for drinks & dinner with friends! The service was wonderful and I loved that we were able to book the reservation the day before using the OpenTable app.
name: The Green Pheasant

text: I kept hearing about this place and oh my goodness, it lived up to the hype. Tried it for the first time Tuesday night and it was so good I had to bring back more friends for dinner Wednesday! First of all, the location directly across from ascend can't be beat. The ambience is super chic and exotic. The signature cocktails are inventive and completely out of the ordinary. But the food--my goodness, the food! The walu appetizer made with escarole sashimi and fresh jalepeño was just delightful. The kinoko mushrooms are exotic and flavorful. The biggest surprise was the chahan--this is not your usual fried rice! It is so incredibly rich and creamy and indulgent! They call them small plates but the portions are quite generous...you'll want to share so you can order a little of everything! And, the servers were so knowledgeable about the ingredients and the origins of the dishes. Our dining experience was simply ideal...twice! Ready to book a third time!
name: The Green Pheasant

text: Such a cool Asian fusion restaurant. Pretty great deals at happy hour, and a really lovely staff. I had the Wagyu beef brisket, and it was really delicious
name: The Green Pheasant

text: This place was great when it first opened. And it still has decent food. But the old menu had Japanese sando's with egg salad, katsu, and even a Wagyu burger. It was awesome and different. However, they quickly changed the menu to bentos and ramen - which is exactly what everyone else is doing. The shokupan was amazing and they really had something special I thought. I also think the parking situation is awful. Kind of a pretentious location.
name: The Green Pheasant

text: Best things about this place are the toilet seats and ambiance. The toilet seats are heated and are Japanese luxury seats with duvets and such. Service was slow. The table wasn't greeted until maybe 15 minutes later, & I asked where our server was. Server seemed annoyed by me when I would ask for something. Guess I was deemed needy, but she was away for long periods at a time. I added lobster tails to our dinner for $10 each. They were the size of a shriveled shrimp. I guess I got what I paid for, but I can get a full lobster tail somewhere else for like $25. The NYE dinner was alright. Wouldn't pay $85 a person here again though. Wagyu wasn't that great, & dessert was just a bunch of mochi that I didn't care for. Serving sizes are tapa sized portions. Even for the entree. My boyfriend was still hungry so I ordered a pizza from Gino's East to be delivered to the house when we left here. I'd go back here for drinks and the fancy toilet seats, but that might just be it.
name: The Green Pheasant

text:
My friend and I originally came here to attend a "Ramen Off" but after seeing that "cheeseburger ramen" was being served we decided to skip it and just eat at the restaurant. The event was held upstairs, and there were plenty of open tables on the dining room floor.

We got there at 5:10 and were put on the waitlist for the Ramen off. At around 5:25 we went up to the hostess stand (there were 3 hostesses) and asked if we could be taken off the list for the event and just dine in downstairs. The hostess asked us to hold on a "moment" and she would seat us. 20 minutes rolls by and it looks like she has no intention to seat us. I asked another hostess who said she couldn't seat us until the person who controlled the seating was back and she was currently on the phone. Again, at least half or more of the tables are open. Another 10-15 minutes till around and that second hostess seats us, in the back of the dining hall, without any apology or care we had to wait for over 30 minutes to sit. I also didn't understand why we were seated in the back when there were plenty of open tables in the front of the restaurant. 

Our service was decent but I felt like she was in a rush. I understand it might have been stressful because an event was taking place upstairs.

The cocktails are good depending on what you get, but I don't know if they're "$14 good." 

The food we ordered was the Tuna Tartare (it was excellent, and my favorite), the Shumai dumplings (my friend liked these, I didn't care for them), the hash browns (these were also very delicious and a nice spin on a traditional American food), and the spicy crab noodles (also pretty good).

All in all, the food is good, the restaurant is beautiful, but for me I appreciate an overall experience and if I feel like a burden to the staff I guarantee you I won't come back no matter how good the food can be. 

Also the heated toilet seats were nice...

Oh and we left the restaurant at 7:00 pm and got a phone call that our table for the Ramen Off was available. We would have had to wait 2 hours and we got there 10 minutes after it started!
name: The Green Pheasant

text: Fantastic Japanese restaurant downtown. Lovely atmosphere, great drinks and the food was lovely. Try the crab noodle dish. Wait staff is excellent, knowledgeable, and helpful in guiding you through the menu. We'll be back!
name: The Green Pheasant

text:
Hard not to give this place 5 stars.  Service was excellent.  All the food was full of flavor and presented very well.  We thought we would leave hungry but that wasn't the case.  Very filling food.  Pricing was of that of top quality food and service in downtown Nashville.
The only thing that kept it from getting 5 stars.  Parking cost $$ for valet.(everywhere I go in Nashville there is no charge for valet even downtown) also you have to have a cc to make a reservation, also the only place I have had to do that.(not a fan of either)
name: The Green Pheasant

text: This place is wonderful date spot! The decor is well thought out with a sense of modern elegance that can be fun and also intimate. I came here for lunch to try out the menu. Although I was craving for dinner menu items, I could only order the lunch menu at the time. The staff is patient and helpful throughout the dining experience from being greeted at the door to the end. I tried the tuna tartare, teishoku kushiyaki set, and also a drink. The tuna tartare came with crispy rice on the bottom and was a bit pricey for the amount and quality/flavor. It wasn't what I had imagined besides two little bites for this dish. I enjoyed the teishoku sets because I like variety. It came with a warm little cup of miso soup, a daily side, rice, and tsukemono. I wasn't very fond of the pickled cucumbers, but the grilled shiitake mushrooms and eggplant were my favorite. The presentation was great, service was great, drinks were refreshing, but I definitely have to come again to try more items. I would definitely come with a group of friends and order a bunch of small dishes to share and just enjoy the night with the amazing decor.
name: The Green Pheasant

text: We went to The Green Pheasant with plans to eat ramen. It turns out they only do ramen at lunch. We mentioned to our sever that we would plan to go to Two Ten Jack for ramen and he went out of his way to call over and get us in line, saving over an hour of time for us. This was unbelievably kind and clutch - shout out server Jason. We didn't get to eat at Green Pheasant and but they have earned lIfelong customers with this kind gesture. 12/10 would recommend. If the owner reads this - please pay your man Jason (dinner from 1/25/2020)
name: The Green Pheasant

text: Went around noon on a Monday and there were only about 4-5 tables having lunch. Sat at the bar - ordered the greens as an appetizer and the moonfish skewers. Very clean flavors, definitely on the subtle seasoning side - but all well prepared and healthy.
name: The Green Pheasant

text:
Disappointed

I made my reservation for a party of 6 two months ago after hearing incredible reviews from co-workers and friends. I was eagerly anticipating a first class experience, an upscale version of another local favorite,Two-Ten Jack. Unfortunately, due to the restaurant management's incompetence and extremely rude and unprofessional attitudes, I left this establishment very disappointed. 

Our reservation was at 7:30pm, and when we arrived, the hostess informed us that our table "was being cleared now" and to take a seat at the bar for a few minutes. After a quick bathroom break, our party ordered a round of drinks from the bar to help us maintain our patience as the minutes melted off of the clock. After 20 minutes of waiting; I approached the host to inquire about the delay in seating. The response was gruff, he rudely informed me that a previous party was still closing out at the table and we would have to continue to wait. I then asked if he would comp our first round of drinks; and again the response was rude and unprofessional- "It's out of my control....Sir!" the manager exclaimed as he shook his head and walked towards the kitchen. 

My party and I continued to wait; ordering a second round of drinks while the waitstaff struggled to get their act together. 50 minutes later, at 8:20pm, the manager finally moped back to the bar; mumbling as he led us upstairs to a completely different section of the restaurant. Before we headed upstairs, I asked him what he would do to help rectify the situation. "The first round of drinks is on me, but I will NOT cover the second." Ridiculous.... 

Once we were seated, I must confess that the remainder of our time was quite enjoyable. From our friendly waiter, Spencer, delicious small plates, and smooth Japanese Whiskey- the second act of the night met my expectations. The heated toilet seats were also a big hit with the ladies. However, none of these positives could cleanse my palate of the sour taste left over from the management's poor demeanor. We shook our heads as we departed; disheartened. I truly believe that the Green Pheasant could fly high with the best of them, as long as it's management stopped clipping it's own wings.
name: The Green Pheasant

text: Food is good and portions are decent, but drinks and food are pricey. $15 for a cocktail full of ice? And glass sizes are small. Waste of money. We're nashville, not New York. Chill on the price hikes.
name: The Green Pheasant

text: After reading the reviews, I knew I had to stop at The Green Pheasant while in Nashville. Fortunately, my flight back to New York got cancelled allowing me one extra night to dine in the Music City. My girlfriend and I got seated without a problem on a cold Sunday January night. We didn't have a reservation, and the restaurant was almost empty. Maybe it was due to the weather? We both commenced with old fashioneds to warm us up, and that was one of the better things we had. To start, we ordered the broccolini appetizer with hot rock shrimp, cornbread, sudachi, shoyu. The fusion didn't work well for me at all. For our main, we shared the spicy crab noodle with crab butter, sweet red crab, tobanjan. And again, nothing to write home about. The creme brule definitely takes the cake here. All in all, it was okay but a little disappointing after having such high hopes.
name: The Green Pheasant

text: Love the food and atmosphere at Green Pheasant. There is some great variety to the menu, as well as the different sections of the restaurant. I'm excited to try some of the other options next time we visit. Definitely try one of the dumpling options if it's your first time.
name: The Green Pheasant

text:
Most of Nashville's new restaurants, while quite good, are not that different from each other.  The Green Pheasant is different.  Japanese-  But far from your average (or even above average) sushi restaurant.  Expect truly interesting, even strange, dishes with SUPERB flavors.  Subtle or powerful depending, light or rich, depending on the dish-  the food here is truly remarkable.  And, you will find dishes you likely have never experienced, (but are worth the try!!) as well as some to please the less than adventurous eater.  If you have never had Japanese wagyu beef -  it's is rare to find it in the US and is considered some of the best beef available in the world.  I'm not a sake fan-  (even cold sake, which is THE thing now) but they have trained sake specialists to help you select!  The wait staff was super knowledgeable, friendly, and helpful.  
The decor and atmosphere is wonderful, with tables having a good amount of space between them so there is some privacy.  In short-  try this place!!!!
name: The Green Pheasant

text: I went with a group of ten ladies on z weeknight. I ordered the chicken small plate at $22. I disliked it and asked the waitress to box the remaining in case somebody in my household would like it. Half the table wanted to share plates and half the table ordered a solo plate for themselves because we did not want a large meal. The restaurant was not able to accommodate this when it came time to billing. So those of us that ordered one item as an entree were not able to get our own check. Nobody in my household like the chicken dish so not a good evening for dining out. The valet parking was a fixed $12 per car.  We were in a beautifully decorated private room.  The group was largely not overwhelmed with the flavors and their menu selections.
name: The Green Pheasant

text: Had lunch here for the 3rd time yesterday and highly recommend the experience.  It is a perfect place for a quiet business lunch.  Very comfortable seating, and great, unobtrusive service.  And for me, the food has to be great & interesting, and Green Pheasant scores highly here too.  I have had the Karaage (Japanese fried chicken) each time.  It melts in your mouth, and even though it looks like chicken nuggets, the flavor is tremendous.  I recommend eating it while still hot, as it just tastes better before it cools.  I have also had the gyoza, yakisoba, and tuna tartare.  All were very good.  Small plates is the way I like to eat, and this place fits nicely into that ability to try different things, and not get too full at mid-day.  I need to get here for dinner next.
name: The Green Pheasant

text:
$129.77 later without tax or tip and 12,977% worth the money spent. Yes, baby, yes! Can I get an hallelujah?! I am screaming at the top of my lungs for The Green Pheasant. Alas, I have found my date night spot. Now, if only I had a date to take with me!

That was pretty exciting first paragraph, wasn't it? The breakdown is pretty clear. When you arrive, valet the car with the restaurant. Just do it and quit groaning at the suggestion. This will make your life a whole lot easier for a stress-free starter to your date. Go to the hostess desk where they will seat you for your reservation that you made 2 weeks ago. As they take you to your table, observe the ambiance. Will they take you to the upstairs with the quirky bathrooms? Will they take you to the main dining room where there is a central bar to people watch or are they going to take you to your private dining room with the awesome wallpaper of CCTV cameras and roses? Yes, you read that right. If you are able, take some photos in there because the wallpaper is totally worth a photo of. Most of the restaurant should find itself in a covershoot in Nashville Scene. Who doesn't love green and red velvet everywhere!?

Now that you're seated, take it all in. Check out the menu and inhale all of the quirky offerings on the menu. But before ordering food, get your sake order in and prepare for a toast! You can get that unique cocktail you were eyeing in the next round. This round is about sharing the moment you realized you're about to have one of the best damn dining experiences in Nashville. Kanpai! ('Cheers' in Japanese)

You've looked over the menu and you're going to order 4-5 items between you and your dining companion. They offer everything from vegetarian to what I'd consider a very large unsightly fish on a plate ready for consumption. I don't like whole fish, but the table next to us certainly did! Whatever you palette wishes is Green Pheasant's command.

The experience exceeds just the dining portion. Let's talk service. Carlos was exceptional. Beyond words, topnotch, never missed a beat, glowing service. He was hospitable, prompt, and very nurturing to our table. He never hoovered and we never had to ask for anything. He was like a genie who appeared when I had a fleeting thought of needing a beverage or another glass of water. We also appreciated his knowledge of the cuisine and his mindfulness of our spice-level tolerance. We ordered based on his recommendations and we loved every last thing he suggested.

After 2.5 hours of eating and drinking, it is time to go. Time to wrap up and get going. But, you do not exit without leaving a gigantic tip for the awesome server you just had, and you do not omit grabbing a couple of photos of yourself with your dining partner to capture the experience that will be ingrained in your culinary memory for a life time. Bask in the moment while you can. You'll return soon, but in the meantime, enjoy the moment at this moment.

Have fun? I know I did. Check it out and do it soon!
name: The Green Pheasant

text:
This was our final dinner in Nashville.  We didn't have this one planned out, rather looked at online reviews for nice Asian because we had already had so much heavy, fried cuisine.  This place was a gem!

I called ahead for a reservation but they were booked up for most of the night.   I was told we could sit at the bar and it would be best to come early.   We actually arrived before their dinner hours began, so we sat at the bar and ordered from their small plates.  

Mike was very friendly, helpful, and welcoming.  He concocted a great non-alcoholic drink for me, which I ordered a few of over the course of our meal!   I can't remember exactly what it was, I believe it was made of cranberry juice, soda water, and a generous sprig of rosemary (picture attached).

We started with the edamame, yaki gyoza (pheasant dumplings), tuna tartare, and lobster shumai (lobster and corn dumplings).  Everything was nicely plated and tasted wonderful.

Next up were the famed spicy crab noodles.  Upon arrival of this dish, we quickly realized: a) that it was so good that we had to order another, b) that it was so good that my spouse was going to eat it all so we had to order another, and c) that it was so good that I wasn't going to want to share the dish with my spouse, so we had to order another!  So, we immediately ordered another!   

Also--interesting find--the toilet seats were heated!  

This is a very unique establishment and we were glad to have the opportunity to visit it!   We were happy to find such a friendly place with fresh ingredients and very unique selections for our last big meal in Nashville!
name: The Green Pheasant

text:
We decided to spend our pre-Thanksgiving Tuesday at the Green Pheasant last night. We were not disappointed! The space is sleek, cool and comfortable. The nonstop "house" music was a bit much, and made it somewhat hard to hear dinner conversation, but we understood the vibe that they were shooting for and took it all in stride. The menu is a fantastic mix of classic Japanese izakaya dishes with some larger plates that are great for sharing. I'm not a big fan of menus that list the name of the dish followed by all of the ingredients without an actual description of the preparation, but our server was very familiar with the menu and talked us through everything. We had two of their craft cocktails; they were spot on perfect. Each was a great mix of sweet, sour, bitter and refreshing. 
We ordered Dan Dan Shishito peppers; very reminiscent of Dan Dan Mian,  without the heaviness of the noodles. A great started. That was followed by lobster and spot prawn shu mai; unlike many restaurant dishes that claim to feature lobster, the succulent crustacean was very present in this one. Then a riff on okonomiyaki; a hash brown pancake with traditional okonomiyaki toppings and sauces. It was like an asian latke; perfect for this time of year. We finished with the whole trout, fried and served with thinly sliced cucumbers, asian slaw and steamed buns. The trout was cooked perfectly; it was silky and juicy. One thing to note; for a restaurant that features a sharing menu, a puzzling number of items came out in odd numbers. 5 shu mai, three steamed buns with the trout; Management-how about 6 shu mai and 4 steamed buns so a pair of enthusiastic and hungry diners don't have to fight over the "odd bun out"? 

In any event, the food was fabulous, and the bill for the meal, with 2 craft cocktails, came out to less than $100. Do yourself a favor and get to the Green Pheasant early and often!
name: The Green Pheasant

text:
My husband and I have been longtime fans of Green Pheasant and Two Ten and recently took some friends. For context most of us are gluten free and dairy free and some of us avoid red meat.

The new layout of the menu made it super easy to make great choices. Our server, who was friendly and attentive, didn't seem to know what was and was not compliant but did make sure to talk to the kitchen for us and made a great sake recommendation. 

Outside our normal faves (Tebasaki Gyoza, tuna tartare and wedges), we loved the new cold additions, including the yellowtail sashimi. And the fries were great!

Fun vibe and great meal. It's our go to for whenever we are downtown.
name: The Green Pheasant

text:
This place was terrible!
The ambience was great. 
But!!!
Our waiter had a lumberjack flannel shirt with a baseball cap.
Our appetizer was a smoked Bok Choi that was extremely watery and had a terrible taste.
Also had the spicy crab noodle dish which was very small with mediocre taste.
The Sui Gyoza we are very small and handle very little flavor.
You have to pay your bill at the tour and we had to actually find somebody at the cash register.
Very pretentious and expensive with small portions.
name: The Green Pheasant

text: Went to this place a few days ago for lunch with coworkers, as our office is right up the block. Couldn't be more disappointed. For the price, it was atrocious. Paid $14 for a rice and chicken dish, which had absolutely no flavor at all. Had to douse it in chill oil and soy sauce to get any flavor. Worse part they charged us for the soy sauce, chill oil, and spices ($2-3 each). If you're in the mood for a flavorless $20 lunch, come here. Otherwise, keep walking. Can't believe I'm saying this, but even the food in a Broadway honky tonk is better than this sad excuse for a restaurant.
name: The Green Pheasant

text:
The Green Pheasant is a fantastic addition to the Nashville food scene! 

Food: We had the Kinoko Mushroom Medley and Dandan Shishito Peppers -- both were fantastic. The broth/sauce in the mushroom dish was perhaps one of the best things I've eaten this year.

Bar Menu: Good selection of sake and other liquors. The staff are knowledgable and willing to help you find a sake that suits your palate. We had the whiskey barrel-aged sake which was served in a jar that you open yourself -- fun! Bartender Mike was friendly and remembered me the next time I came in.

Ambiance: The mid-century vibe meshed with Japanese culture seems a bit odd when you break it all down into individual parts but together, as a whole, the place is totally Nashville and just works. The decor is hip and on-trend while still sending out a warm and inviting ambiance. I LOVE the die-cut booth dividers which still let in light but create a nice division of space. 

My only wish would be for a more diverse Happy Hour drink menu, which currently features sake and beer. How about bubbly and whiskey?

All in all, The Green Pheasant is a wonderful date night, after-work light bites, or a classy kick-start to your Broadway tourist experience.
name: The Green Pheasant

text: Way pricier than I thought it would be and some of the front staff were not pleasant, but the food is absolutely amazing and so is the ambiance. I would definitely return for a drink and an appetizer or something but not again when I'm starving because I'm just too poor to fork out a few hundred dollars for a meal with one other person. Portions are very small.
name: The Green Pheasant

text:
The Green Pheasant was probably one of the worst dining experiences I've had to date and I dine out frequently, globally, so I feel I've got decent perspective. It started with check-in and seating. When we arrived, the two hosts, clearly flustered and whom I felt badly for if I'm being honest as they were overwhelmed, were arguing with each other over a table that had been somehow mis-seated. They audibly (and in front of other guests) tried to work this issue out but meanwhile let other guests linger in the very small waiting area in the front without explanation. 

After checking-in at 8:10pm for our 8:15pm reservation, we were told our table wasn't yet ready and when we asked approximately how long the wait would be, we were told "tables are just lingering, so please head to the bar." Anyone who's worked in the Industry understands occasionally this happens after check drops, especially on weekends, however to my surprise upon walking in the dining room I observe multiple open tables/tables that need to be serviced and flipped. 

We are forced to sit at the bar (where the service was really less than stellar and/or quick) until 8:45pm and I'm convinced the only reason we got a table is because a member of our party kept continually checking in with the host to inquire about our reservation. 

Once seated (and starving), we received a brief apology from our server and he noted that this "happens around the 8pm reservation time sometimes," so it seems like this seating delay is a common problem Green Pheasant is aware of. We immediately ordered some dishes because we were starving. Since the first two were raw foods, they were delivered to us fairly quickly. The rest took FOREVER. We were told the kitchen was very backed up and they'd come out as they were ready. To say this was frustrating after our wait to be seated was an understatement. 

I observed a manager on the restaurant floor in our area only once throughout the night. He never did a table touch to ask about or experience in general, or to apologize for the wait for the table or food delays. There was no good faith gesture of any sort or acknowledgement from the restaurant regarding our experience beyond the very brief apology from our server, who obviously doesn't control the kitchen volume. 

The food was decent but to be honest, I was so hungry by the time any food came out, I would have eaten just about anything. 

To summarize, I would never return to The Green Pheasant and am baffled by the positive reviews of this restaurant given what I experienced, observed, and discussed with fellow diners while at the restaurant. What an extremely disappointing (and pricey!) experience.
name: The Green Pheasant

text: Easily one of the best restaurants I've been to in my life. They lobster corn dumplings are single bites of some of the best food you could ever have. Their chicken, shrimp wing is incredible. I dream of eating here again.
name: The Green Pheasant

text: We had a large group of 11 people, so we were able to try almost everything on the menu, and I would definitely eat it all again. Some standouts: sunomono, broccolini, curry udon, tebasaki gyoza (so crispy!!), ikinari steak. Everything was so flavorful and we were all so pleased with everything by the end of our meal. Leave room for dessert! It's definitely worth it! And on top of a delicious meal, the restaurant is gorgeous!
name: The Green Pheasant

text: Service was not the best for the price of the tab, but a pretty interesting place to go to! The inside looks amazing
name: The Green Pheasant

text:
Unreal and incredible food. We did 4 apps and the skirt steak along with the yakisoba. Flavor in everything was perfect. I wished we weren't in a hotel for the week and we could have taken left overs! 
Highly recommend.
name: The Green Pheasant

text:
I do not understand the 5 star reviews. We really wanted to love this place. The restaurant is beautiful and the concept is admirable. However the food is very disappointing. 
We started with shishito peppers which turned out to be the best of what we had tonight. Good but not so great I would return just for that. We had the tuna tartar which had a decent flavor but was warm and chopped up so much that one would wonder if they were trying to hide that they were using poor quality tuna. Imagine room temperature cat food on top of warm rice cake. The whole thing did not work. 
Then to the entree. The steak was good but salty. The spicy crab pasta which is their signature dish came out cold and way after the steak. When we told the waiter it was cool, we were told it was because the noodle was rinsed and would never be piping hot. I'm sorry but a bit warmer than cold doesn't cut it. This was also very salty and I was told it was because I asked for spicy and they added chili sauce. Really?  The chef does not know how to make things spicier without making it so salty you can't eat?  So to save time and by this point my husband had already finished his steak so I asked for some plain hot noodles to be added. 
They brought some dumplings while waiting which was a nice touch but please don't bother ordering. They are less than tasty. 

Finally the noodles came out and they added garlic butter which made the plain pasta salty again. JAPANESE FOOD DOES NOT HAVE TO BE SALTY. 
By now we were ready to get out of this pretentious place. The bill came out and they had charged us 14 for the noodles. So they charged 26 for salty lukewarm entree that was not edible as it was, then charged 14 more for what I had hoped to be warm plain noodles. So basically we were asked to pay 40 for a mediocre dish. We complained and they took it off the bill but that should have never happened. 

My prediction is that the place would not survive if they do not improve the quality of their food. You cannot survive on looks and cool vibe alone.
name: The Green Pheasant

text: Service and atmosphere are great but the food was awful! We ordered several cold/hot options and all left hungry and disappointed. Definitely not worth the price!
name: The Green Pheasant

text: This place is delicious in the way it taste and looks! The menu is always changing which is fun. I went with a group of girls and we ordered almost everything on the menu. This place is all tapas so if you are hungry and want to eat quickly you'll have to be patient. It's best when you can just enjoy the food slowly. There were moments that I tried something and I wanted to stop time- it was a burst of flavor in my mouth. My favorites are the tuna tartare and the lobster dumplings. Order a little at a time and see where the night takes you!
name: The Green Pheasant
